subject: Productivity
title: Taylor and the Efficiency Movement
description: Learn Taylor and the Efficiency Movement in one minute.

hook.text: Frederick Taylor believed there was one best way to do any task. His stopwatch would find it.

buildup.text: Scientific management broke work into timed, optimized motions. Efficiency became a religion.

discovery.text: Taylor's time studies at Bethlehem Steel tripled pig-iron output. The results were undeniable.

twist.text: Workers weren't consulted. Taylor treated them as parts of a machine. Strikes and resentment followed.

climax.text: Taylorism split opinion: visionary to some, dehumanizing to others. Both sides had evidence.

punchline.text: Efficiency without dignity is just faster misery.

quiz.question: What was the core idea of Frederick Taylor's scientific management?
options: Finding the one best way to do any task through time studies
Letting workers choose their own methods
